title: Special deal protects diplomat’s wife suspected of hit-and-run that killed teen
text:
Harry Dunn, 19, was killed in an accident near RAF Croughton in Northamptonshire on 27 August

A special deal is reportedly in place protecting a US diplomat’s wife suspected of being involved in a fatal hit-and-run.

Harry Dunn, 19, died after his motorbike was hit by a car driving down the wrong side of a road in Northamptonshire near RAF Croughton, which is used as a United States Air Force communications station.

The woman, married to a US envoy, has been identified as Anne Sacoolas, 42, by Sky News. She claimed diplomatic immunity and left the country after the incident.

Diplomatic immunity normally only covers diplomats and their families based in London.

But Sky News reports there has been a special deal in place since 1994 between the UK and the US for RAF Croughton, which also covers some other sites outside the capital.

Police said initial investigations indicated Harry was riding his vehicle on the correct side of the road, but that a woman hit him head-on after pulling out of the base onto the wrong side.

An attempt by Northamptonshire Police to stop the suspect leaving was declined, and the US Embassy have confirmed she is no longer in the UK.

Business Secretary Andrea Leadsom publicly appealed to the woman to come forward (Picture: Getty Images)

Mr Dunn’s parents have also received a letter from Woody Johnson, US Ambassador to the UK, expressing ‘profound sadness’.

Government ministers have called for the American woman to face questioning in the UK.

Business Secretary Andrea Leadsom, who is the family’s local MP in South Northamptonshire, called on the woman to step forward.

She said: ‘Obviously I’m going to do everything I can to make sure they get justice for Harry.’

‘But, at the same time, I would appeal over the head of the Foreign Office to the woman; it was an accident from all accounts – obviously I wasn’t there and it needs a police investigation – but surely she must see that this family needs closure.’

Mr Dunn’s father Tim said: ‘We’re disgusted, appalled. How could she be having this cloak wrapped around her?

‘I’m angry someone could do this then get on a plane and go. I can’t believe she’s living with herself.’

A campaign group called Justice For Harry has been set up on social media and has raised over £4000 of its £10,000 target though a gofundme page.
